A histogram clearly shows distribution (or shape) of the data along with clearly showing the locations of the median and mode averages.

The dorsal stream recognises where things are very quickly. It helps us avoid obstacles when walking and running.

body: Which visual features can you use to make information 'pop'

You can use colour, texture, position and size to make information pop. It is best, however,  to use a combination of features. For example a thick red line, not just a red line.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You can use colour, texture, position and size to make information pop. It is best, however,  to use a combination of features. For example a thick red line, not just a red line.

body:
What is the maximum number of tables that you should have on each sheet of a spreadsheet?

Hint: The number of tables per sheet should equal the number of records per row.
title: Q: How many tables per sheet?
instruction: Select one option and then click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

You should only have one table per sheet and one record per row. This will make processing and filtering the data easier. Don't use your spreadsheet to make data look pretty at time of collection, use it to collect accurate data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

You should only have one table per sheet and one record per row. This will make processing and filtering the data easier. Don't use your spreadsheet to make data look pretty at time of collection, use it to collect accurate data.

body: Which of the column titles below would be the most appropriate for the name of a healthcare facility?
displayTitle: Which is the best column title?
title: Q: Which is the best column title?
instruction: Select one answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Be as descriptive as you can with your column titles. Facility name is better than Name as it is specific and clear. You could also expand the title further to Heath care facility name, but if this is clear from the title of the dataset, it may not be necessary.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Be as descriptive as you can with your column titles. Facility name is better than Name as it is specific and clear. You could also expand the title further to Heath care facility name, but if this is clear from the title of the dataset, it may not be necessary.

body: Which data type is best to represent the rating of a facility on a scale of 0-5 stars?
title: Q: Which data type?
instruction: Pick one answer and click submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

When recording data that is on a scale, it is best to use numbers which can be easily sorted. Using text such as 1 star limits how the data can be used. Avoid custom data types that cannot be not easily sorted (e.g. ★★★).

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

When recording data that is on a scale, it is best to use numbers which can be easily sorted. Using text such as 1 star limits how the data can be used. Avoid custom data types that cannot be not easily sorted (e.g. ★★★).

body:
You have a dataset containing the grades of students attending every school in the country in a single sheet. Your dataset is over 100,000 rows in length. 

If you want to look at only the results from a single school, what should you do?
title: Q: Exploring large datasets

_items.text: Sort the dataset and scroll to find the school
Change the way that the data is collected such that the data about each school is in a separate sheet
Use a filter to show only the data for that sheet
Manually create a new sheet with the data in

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

With all the data in one sheet, you can use filters to quickly look at any custom selection of the data. While it might seem logical to split data of this size into several sheets, the instant ability to analyse all the data is lost.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

With all the data in one sheet, you can use filters to quickly look at any custom selection of the data. While it might seem logical to split data of this size into several sheets, the instant ability to analyse all the data is lost.

body:
Data has the potential to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

In this module, we explore how governments, businesses and individuals are using open data to create new value.

In this module we’ll explore:

  • Innovation and growth in businesses
  • Opportunities for governments
  • Impact on society and public policy
  • Corporate and Social Responsibility (CSR)
title: Unlocking value from open data

body: Organisations are increasingly using data to...
title: Q: Why do we need data?

_items.text: understand how their business works and how they perform
unlock social, environmental and economic value

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Whether in operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Whether in operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses large and small to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

In the UK, startup Provenance is using open data to help companies become more transparent about their supply chains, while international music streaming service Spotify sources its metadata about artists from open music encyclopedia MusicBrainz.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

Data literacy is a core skill for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.
title: Innovation and growth in businesses

body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
title: Opportunities for government
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Supporting growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, governments need to publish key datasets.

Governments also need to support data infrastructure that connects data with those who use it.

In return, governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy, such as in Finland where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Governments need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to improving delivery of services at the local level.

Some of these new services are available now:

Take me to mySociety

Take me to Data Mill North

Take me to Fix my Street UK

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
Open data allows governments to make savings in key areas such as healthcare, education and utilities.

In the UK, open data helped reveal £200 million of savings in the health service.

In France, energy data is being used to drive more efficient energy generation practices.
Show me the France energy data.

Open data can also bring transparency to budgets. In Switzerland, the canton of Bern presented their €400m annual saving to the public using open data.

body: Open data is unlocking new social value and enabling better targeted public policies.
title: Changing societies and public policy
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Improving the way we move
_items.body:
Open data has the power to revolutionise the way we travel.

All over the world open transport data allows companies like Citymapper and Google to give people accurate transport information. This not only helps people understand and use complex transport systems, it also decreases the number of people in cars and increases revenue for public transport systems.

Efforts have already begun in Tanzania to open up transport data relating to the Dar es Salaam rapid transit system. The data is being collected and made available through openstreetmap, a collaborative tool that enables anyone to access and use the data, even commercially.

Take me to the DART data on openstreetmap

Within the Dutch transport industry, open data is helping a growing number of small companies to develop new services.

A new Dutch app GoOV, winner of the prestigious Apps4Europe competition, helps disabled people to book travel assistance for their journeys using open data.

Take me to information about GoOV

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and helps tourists to travel in unfamiliar cities.

_items.title: Improving the way we work
_items.body:
Open data is changing the way we work.

Open data reduces the time needed to find information and allows professionals to focus more of their time on productive activities.

OpenCorporates offers an open database of companies around the world, showing their networks, financial stability and environmental impact. This helps organisations learn more about prospective clients, providers and partners.
Take me to OpenCorporates

_items.title: Improving the way we govern
_items.body:
Open data is becoming a key source of evidence for governments in the policymaking process.

Open data is also making the development of public policy more transparent and supporting dialogue between governments and citizens.

Open data on key issues such as immigration, trade and budget cuts can be used to inform important policy decisions.

For example, an analysis of the open data around fire station closures in london helped demonstrate which stations could be closed with the least impact on services.

Take me to London fire station analysis

body: Open data is helping people target initiatives for cultural and environmental benefits.
title: Corporate and Social Responsibility (CSR)
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Environment
_items.body:
Open data helps farmers to improve yields and support a growing population without the need to destroy valuable habitats.

Syngenta publish open data on agriculture efficiency indicators as part of their ‘Good Growth Plan’, which sets out key commitments for ensuing global food security.

The Climate Corporation, which began as a startup using open weather data to provide weather insurance to farmers, was acquired by Monsanto for $1.1bn USD in 2013.

_items.title: Saving lives
_items.body:
Open data is helping to save lives.

In response to the 2010 Haiti earthquake, Google made its geographic data available to humanitarian groups to deliver targeted supplies in disaster zones.

Show me the Haiti Open Street Map.

This led to Google Crisis Response, an open source project that anyone can contribute to in times of humanitarian need.

displayTitle: Are you ready to unlock value from open data?
title: Are you ready to unlock value from open data?

body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.

Data is a valuable resource to organisations of all sizes.  Increasing numbers of organisations are using data to grow their businesses, improve their operations and enhance services for their customers.

In the next module, we will explore how value is unlocked from open data.

Next module
title: Summary

body:
Open data has the power to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

Open data can help governments grow economies, improve service delivery and save on costs.

Open data can benefit society by improving the ways we move, the ways we work and the ways we govern.

Open data can help save lives and help us better understand the world in which we live.

Ready to get involved? In the next module, we explore how to convince your colleagues about the benefits of improved data usage.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
title: What is data?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

Collecting and presenting data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

body: What is the benefit of having open transport data?
title: Q: Changing society and public policy

_items.text: It saves people time and improves access

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and streamlines access for tourists.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open transport data saves commuters time, makes journeys more accessible and streamlines access for tourists.

body: What type of open data was used to help in disaster response efforts in Haiti?
title: Q: Changing culture and environment

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In response to the 2010 Haiti earthquake, Google made it open geographic data available to humanitarian groups to deliver targeted supplies in disaster zones.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

In response to the 2010 Haiti earthquake, Google made it open geographic data available to humanitarian groups to deliver targeted supplies in disaster zones.

body:
You should start your elevator pitch by outlining the problem you are solving for your users. This is known as the value proposition.

The value proposition of a business is central to its business model as it provides a justification for why the business operates.

Top tip: think of your value proposition as the abstract or executive summary of your solution. Keep it short, keep it snappy and use a list of three.

For example: improved data usage grows your business, improves services for consumers and saves you save time and money.
title: What problem are you solving?

body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for a dataset to be useful.
title: Community-driven standards
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

body:
Data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it. However simply sharing a data file does not guarantee it is usable. It is unlikely that users will be able to properly engage with unusable data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits. 

Following standards and applying quality marques will help increase the usability of data.

In the next module, we look at how to organise data ready for analysis.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
Assessing how usable data is cannot be done quickly.

There are a number of community-based standards and quality marques that can help you assess how usable data is, summarised in this module with a simple checklist.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is data quality?
  • Community standards
  • Lloyd's data quality principles
  • Data quality checklist
title: What makes quality data

body: Can you recall the practical, technical, legal and social requirements for a dataset to be useful?
title: Can you explain usable data?

body:
It is important to plan your time carefully in any data project. Follow these steps to help you plan efficiently.

The 80:20 rule for data storytelling

Gathering, organising, filtering and cleaning of data will take 80% of your time. Done right this can significantly reduce the time you spend in the analysis and visualisation.

Develop your narrative at the beginning

Much like research has a hypothesis to test from the start, it is useful to spend the first stages of a project outlining the audience and narrative. This will help keep the data collection focussed and time to a minimum.
title: Planning your time

body:
One of the most challenging parts of using data is communicating your findings to others, or telling a story with your data. To be successful, you need to understand the four step data storytelling process and how to plan your time effectively at every stage.

In this module we will introduce:

  • The four step data storytelling process
  • Stages of the four step process
  • Planning your time
displayTitle: A four step approach to storytelling with data
title: A four step approach to storytelling with data

body:
According to information architect and multimedia journalist Mirko Lorenz, data-driven storytelling is primarily a workflow that consists of the four steps:

  1. Gathering data
  2. Filtering and analysing the data
  3. Visualising the data
  4. Making a story

The value of data increases as it turns into a story. Those who work with data must be able to communicate why it is important or useful, otherwise the value is lost.
displayTitle: The four step data storytelling process
title: The four step data storytelling process

displayTitle: Are you ready to start the four step process?
title: Are you ready to start the four step process?

body:
The four step process combined data and analysis skills with key learnings from journalism. It is just as important to communicate the results of your analysis, as it is to conduct a sophisticated data analysis. Mastering both skills can be challenging, however is essential to draw the real value from data.

Follow other modules on this course to discover more about each stage, and learn how to master each particular skill.

In the next module we explore how to find and gather data. 

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
Data is not always easy to find on the Web, because most of the available resources are only visible to machines. People navigate the Web visually; viewing content, clicking on links and downloading files.

Machines, by contrast, only navigate the Web through logical rules set out in the code. While humans look for engaging, interactive content, machines require structure, logic and clarity.

This difference creates ‘blind spots’ for how people and machines read the Web. 

Downloadable data is data that is designed for humans to access, for example through a download button. Hidden data is data that is designed for machines to access, for example through structured code.
title: Downloadable and hidden data

body: The problem with downloading data is that you have taken the data away from its source. This means that your copy could now be out of data. Leaving data at its source and using services such as APIs to access this data eliminates this problem and provides other benefits as well.
title: Benefits of hidden data
instruction: Explore the benefits unlocking hidden data can bring below.

_items.title: Quality
_items.body:
In many cases hidden data will be data used by a publisher to present the webpage you are looking at on their site.

The hidden data is therefore an important part of their online operations and it is likely that the publisher takes care over its quality.

Data extracted from the Web tends to be more reliable as it is likely to be data at the core of an organisation's operations. Therefore, it is more likely to be a dependable data source to work with.

_items.title: Relevance
_items.body:
Organisations do not always publish downloadable data. However, many of them run data-driven websites. By accessing the data directly through existing data feeds (or from within the website’s code) there is a clear use for the data already. This will help you to quickly identify relevant data from this existing use, rather than having to establish the use yourself. For example, the BBC News pages, sections and related data feeds
Take me to BBC news feeds

_items.title: Context
_items.body: When you access data directly from the Web you are already viewing it in a context it is used in by the publisher. As we have covered in previous modules, the context of the data is an important component of its use.

_items.title: Breadth
_items.body: Often an organisation is limited in the amount of data it can publish as downloadable data. Finding hidden data opens up a broader range of resources.

body:
The growing demand for data has led to an increase in human friendly data services, including data portals and simple download buttons. However, downloadable data represents only a small fraction of the available data on the Web. The majority of data available on the Web is hidden from the human eye. But machines can find and read this data.

In this module we explore the following: 

  • The difference between downloadable and hidden data
  • Finding downloadable data
  • Finding hidden data
  • The benefits of using hidden data
title: Gathering data

body: Search engines (like Google) can be used to find data by...
displayTitle: How do you search for data?
title: Q: How do you search for data?

_items.text: Including the word data in the search

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Search engines have advanced search functions which enable you to quickly filter search results. For example adding "filetype:xls" to a Google search will return only Microsoft Excel files rather than web pages.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Search engines have advanced search functions which enable you to quickly filter search results. For example adding "filetype:xls" to a Google search will return only Microsoft Excel files rather than web pages.

body:
The ability to gather data from many sources is a key one for any modern data worker. The ability to confidently use advanced search engine features as well as more complex mechanisms like Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) will help unlock a whole web of data that you might not have even known existed. 

In the next module we look at how to ensure that the data you have gathered is of sufficient quality.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
A common challenge in ensuring data quality is difficulties people face when using spreadsheets. When data is properly managed, it is much easier to answer fundamental questions and conduct analysis. Correctly managed data also ensures you aren't making decisions based on faulty evidence. Knowing how to structure and organise data in a spreadsheet is fundamental to ensuring consistency in your data. 

In this module we look at how to effectively structure a spreadsheet for raw data collection. We will cover:

  • Spreadsheet layouts
  • Column titles 
  • Header rows and the freeze function
  • Data types

At the end of this module you can try out what you've learnt on a spreadsheet.
title: Organising data

body:
Effective organisation and careful management of data makes it easier to ensure data quality, and analyse or visualise results. The first step is understanding the basics of a spreadsheet and creating a good template in which to collect data. 

Discover the fundamentals of spreadsheet layouts below.
title: Spreadsheet layouts
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Rows, columns and values
_items.body:
Ensure you understand these important aspects and use them correctly.

Rows: A row represents a single record in your collection. For example in a dataset of companies, each row must represent a single company and in a dataset of health facilities, each row must only represent a single facility. 

Columns: A column defines a feature (or field) for every record. For example in a dataset of people a good field to collect would be "first name".

Values: Values are what is recorded in each row/column. For example "Emily" would be the value for the "first name" of a single person in a dataset of people.

_items.title: Sheets and multiple sheets
_items.body:
Each sheet in a spreadsheet should only contain one table.

Start your table at row 1, column 1 (top left corner).

Avoid adding multiple tables starting in different parts of the sheet (e.g. column L row 16).

You should also avoid using multiple sheets unless it is necessary to collect multiple different datasets in one spreadsheet. 

For example, if you are collecting a dataset of companies, add them all to a single sheet and avoid dividing them by type or location of company. You may end up with a sheet containing many thousands of rows, however it is easier to filter a single sheet than multiple sheets.

Module 9 looks at filtering data in a spreadsheet in more detail.

body:
Column titles are essential to ensuring that data can be collected and used correctly.

Keep your column titles clear, concise and relevant to the dataset. Avoid using acronyms or other abbreviations, as they can be confusing.

If you are collecting numbers in your data, don't forget to define the units and be as clear as possible in the description. For example: "Cost ($millions)" would be a clearer title than "Cost" or "Cost ($m)".

Make sure your column titles are only contained in a single row – preferably the first row in the spreadsheet, starting at A,1.
title: Perfect column titles

body:
The freeze function is useful when viewing, managing and organising large datasets. It 'freezes' the column titles at the top of the page, so you can always check your value against the associated row and column, without scrolling back up to the top. 

This function can be accessed from the 'View' menu of most spreadsheet applications.
displayTitle: Header rows and the freeze function
title: Header rows and the freeze function

body:
Values contained in a single column should be consistent in their type. For example, in a First name column you would use text, an Age column would contain numbers, a Date of birth should contain dates.  

When collecting data, ensure that all your entries are expressed in the same type of value. For example if you have an age column, you should change any text entries to numbers to make sure they match up. In the majority of spreadsheet applications you can enforce the criteria of the data type per column by going to 'Validation' from the 'Data' button in the menu.
title: Data types

_items.title: Text/string
_items.body:
This data type is the most flexible and allows any combination of characters to make a sentence.

e.g. Emily, 2nd Royal Artillery

_items.title: Numbers
_items.body: Numbers can include whole numbers (otherwise known as 'integers') such as 1, 12, 312 etc, or decimal numbers, such as 1.25, 32.789. Be careful with the UK decimal point (2.5) and the European decimal point (2,5).

_items.title: Date
_items.body:
Picking a consistent format for dates is crucial. You can choose how you want to display it (e.g. 2016-09-14) or use the one built into the spreadsheet application. 

As dates can be presented in many different ways, it is recommended that you validate them (check for correctness and consistency) on collection by going to 'Data' in the menu bar and choosing 'Validation'. However, this does not always work if the American form (MM/DD/YYYY) and European form (DD/MM/YYYY) are used interchangeably - it would be impossible to determine whether the date '04/05/2016' would mean the fourth of May, or fifth of April.

_items.title: Defined options
_items.body:
Data types can also be defined options, such as true or false, yes or no, or a limited range of text or numbers. 

You can use the validation function to ensure that a user can only enter valid values.

displayTitle: Are you ready to organise your data correctly?
title: Are you ready to organise your data correctly?

body:
The 'format' of a dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format helps ensure the data can by simply managed, shared and reused. To maximise reuse of data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • Why formats matter to data
  • Choosing the right structure
  • Choosing the right format
  • Using multiple formats and structures
title: Formatting data

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why formats matter for open data publishers and why CSV is a good starting point for sharing data openly.
title: Open data formats
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body: Not all data can be appropriately expressed as a spreadsheet. Different file formats may have to be considered. There are three key structures to be aware of: tabular, hierarchical and network.
title: Common data structures
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Tabular
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. An example of appropriate tabular data is the Italian data portal’s museum attendance figures.
Take me to Italian Data Portal

_items.title: Hierarchical
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a hierarchical data structure in a format such as JSON is ideal. An example of appropriate hierarchical data is this JSON file from json.org
Take me to the json.org example

_items.title: Network
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure is a social network. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook; consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

The Web is another example of a network data structure, where webpages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

body:
As a user of open data, it is important to understand how publishers are delivering different formats to you for reuse.

Not all data is suitable for download either because it is too large, too regularly updated or too complex to expose as static files. Some data may need to be split into smaller parts. Other data may need to be published as live feeds to make sure it stays up-to-date.
displayTitle: Finding open data in the right formats
title: Finding open data in the right formats
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Downloadable open data
_items.body:
Tabular data is the best suited for download. This is why most government open data portals are predominantly tabular data. However, managing millions of rows of data may need other considerations:

  • Should the data be split into smaller datasets?
  • How often should the data be updated?
  • How will changes in the way you publish affect the previous releases?

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file.

Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also know as an application programming interface (API).

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the Web. These services can be directly integrated into other Web applications.  For an example of an open data API, see the Met Office API.

body:
Geospatial data is often more complex than simple tabular datasets.

It can exist as a hierarchical dataset, detailing countries and counties/states, or as a network dataset, detailing roads.

When publishing this type of data, formats like geoJSON (based upon JavaScript Object Notation - JSON) and KML (based upon Extensible Markup Language - XML) should be considered.

These formats are specifically designed with usability in mind and can easily be imported and exported from specialist mapping tools like Open Street Map and CartoDB.
title: Geospatial open data formats

body:
The 'format' of a dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format helps ensure the data can by simply managed and reused. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

Wherever possible, the CSV file format should be used for sharing data. CSV is a simple to understand, highly reusable and machine-readable format.

At the point where you have structured your data, you may think it’s ready for processing or even visualising. As discovered earlier in the four step process, this is unfortunately not the case as you need to ensure that your data is of clean and accurate.

In the next module we explore how to clean data.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body: Test your knowledge on open data formats with our questions. Can you recall the important points?
title: Are your formats in order?

displayTitle: Choosing the right format for sharing data
title: Choosing the right format for sharing data
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more
mobileInstruction: Click the '+' button to see more

_items.title: Start with CSV
_items.body:
When it comes to sharing data that everyone can use, start with CSV.

A comma separated values (CSV) file is simply lines of data, with each data point separated from the next by a comma. CSV is perfect for tabular data and can be easily loaded into and saved from applications like Excel, making it accessible to users.

Although CSV doesn’t maintain formatting and graphs like Excel formats, it is an open, machine-readable format. CSV represents the simplest format that still supports broad reuse of data. In other words, CSV is the ‘lowest common denominator’ for data.

_items.title: Overcoming the limitations of CSV.
_items.body:
As CSV is such a simple format, this also means that CSV cannot be used to share complex structured data or data that contains dynamic elements. 

For example, when you share create a CSV from an excel spreadsheet you will lose formatting, formula, graphs and other stylistic elements. 

In this case it may be necessary to consider sharing the source format of the data. For data files sharing the Excel file may be a logical next step even before CSV.

_items.title: Sharing complex data structures
_items.body:
If data is structured as a hierarchy or network then it may be worth making access available to the data via an Application Programme Interface (API). 

APIs allow the querying and accessing of their data in a consistent way. Often the API will closely match the structure of the database and expose an SQL (Structured Query Language) like interface to the data. 

In order to use such services, clear documentation should be provide on the structure of the data with examples of how it can be accessed.

Lloyd's shares its data via the data directory.

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why clean open data is important, how to clean open data you find and what tools are available to support you.
title: Data cleaning – in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body: Without clean data, we can’t build information. There are a number of useful tools that can help the process of cleaning data.
title: The data-cleaning toolkit
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: The data-cleaning toolkit
_items.body:
When you are looking for errors in data, it may be necessary to download and upload datasets in many tools for cleaning and processing.

It is also important to keep a note of what changes have been made and share these openly with others so that everyone can benefit from your work, particularly if the data you are cleaning is existing open data that has been published.

In this section we look at two of the main tools and their uses:

  • Open Refine
  • Excel (and similar spreadsheet programmes)

_items.title: Open Refine
_items.body:
Open Refine is a software tool designed to deal with uncleaned data. The tool is a column-based browser that allows you to fix errors across an entire open dataset in a single action. The errors that can be fixed include:

  • Date formats
  • Multiple representations
  • Duplicate records
  • Redundant data
  • Mixed numerical scales
  • Mixed ranges

_items.title: Excel
_items.body:
Open Refine is a key tool for cleaning data. However, it is sometimes easier to fix some errors in Excel (or similar spreadsheet programmes):

  • Spelling errors
  • Redundant data
  • Numerical verification
  • Fixing shifted data

body: Can you recall the reasons why data needs to be cleaned, the useful tools to use and which common errors you should look for in datasets?
displayTitle: Are you ready to clean data?
title: Are you ready to clean data?

body:
Although your data may be adequately managed, often a raw dataset can be riddled with errors. Errors are often not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over time. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like typos or incorrect abbreviations.

When working with any data, it is important to know how to find errors and correct them to make the data more useful.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • Common data errors
  • Useful data cleaning tools
  • Benefits of cleaning data
title: Cleaning data

body:
Knowing that your data is clean is important to ensure you have a reliable starting point when using a dataset and creating new value from it.

Clean data is data that is consistent, free from duplication and ready for machine consumption.

If data is clean, it is easier to combine with different datasets and find deeper insights.
displayTitle: What do we mean by clean data?
title: What do we mean by clean data?

body:
Data-cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. Errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.

Follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

Get started with data cleaning in Open Refine

Once data is clean, it is ready for analysis. This analysis does not have to use complex statistical methods. This analysis does not have to use complex statistical methods; in fact comfortable using common analysis techniques such as pivot tables can be equally, if not more, effective.

In the next module, we explore how to sort and filter pivot tables in spreadsheets.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body: In addition to the tools that can be used to clean open data, it is important to understand the benefits that cleaning brings.
displayTitle: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
title: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Prioritise cleaning
_items.body:
If data is not clean then decisions made on the basis of it could be wrong. This can affect products or insights you develop from data and, in some cases, have an impact upon thousands or even millions of people.

A recent study found that the process of preparing data for analysis can take anywhere between 60% and 80% of the time of a data-driven project.

_items.title: Enhance usability
_items.body:
Sharing a clean open dataset will make the data more usable. Tools like Open Refine allow you to share change history, letting people know what has been cleaned and how. Making the process open as well as the data adds to the sustainability and trust a user can put in a dataset.

There are also data-cleaning communities emerging that could be supported more actively, such as OpenStreetMap communities.

Take me to OSM Denmark Community Wiki

_items.title: Discover insights
_items.body:
Many data-cleaning tools, including Open Refine, help you to combine and enrich datasets. This can lead to valuable insights being discovered.

For example, enriching a dataset that refers to businesses (by name or some other identifier) can inform you if the business is still trading and its current financial position.

Get started with enriching data.

body:
Sorting and filtering data helps you to see trends in the data. 

Before applying any sort or filter operations, make sure that you have frozen the header rows.

Use the video on the right to help guide you.
title: Sorting and filtering data

_items.title: Sorting data
_items.body:
To sort a column, simply select the column header you want to sort the data by and then select the sort option, normally available from the Data menu or panel in most spreadsheet applications.

You can then choose how you want to sort the data.

_items.title: Filtering data
_items.body:
Filters allow you to limit the data that you see.

To apply a filter, select any cell in your header row and click the filter icon. This is normally available from the same place that the sort function is found.

Once selected, you will notice that your header row gains a dropdown option. Selecting or unselecting the data shown in this dropdown will allow you to both sort and filter the values in a row. This will hide the data, but not get rid of it.

body:
Combining all aspects of this module enables you to create a simple data analysis tool for our spreadsheet of data.

Follow the steps below to create your own data analysis interface for healthcare facilities:
title: Data analysis

_items.title: Advanced pivot table
_items.body:
The first stage is to create a new pivot data from our complete dataset. In this case we are going to look at the star rating of heathcare facilities per region.

This time the region will be the row labels. The column headings will represent the star ratings and the values will be the total count of facilities that achieve that star rating.

In order to make filtering and analysing easier, it is recommended that only a total row for column totals be added.

_items.title: Create a graph
_items.body:
The next stage is creating a graph of the data in our pivot table. 

Simply highlight the data, including row and column titles, and click the charting tool. We want to add a clustered column chart. 

Feel free to name and style your chart to look nice. Try to not have the chart on top of the data.

_items.title: Slice your data
_items.body:
The last stage involves adding a slicer (or filter) to the pivot table. This tool can be found in the pivot table options (or toolbar). 

Add a slicer to your dataset based upon healthcare facility type. This will now allow you to filter the pivot table by type. As the pivot table updates, so will the graph that you made at the previous stage.

body:
In this module we have seen how simple it can be to analyse data once it is organised in the correct structure. 

If you haven't already, try applying what you have learnt to this spreadsheet. 

At this point there are two possible directions. Further analysis may be required to find a story; this may require further gathering, organising and cleaning. You may even need to employ further advanced statistical techniques such as the ones outlined in the courses and exercises linked below.  Alternatively, you might have discovered your story already and be ready to visualise it.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
Once your data is organised and clean, you can now begin to filter and analyse the data.

In this module we will learn how to:

  • Sort and filter data in a spreadsheet
  • Apply formula to generate simple statistics
  • Create a number of pivot tables
  • Create a number of summary graphs

To prepare you for this exercise you will need this spreadsheet. Note that it has two sheets; the first tab holds the data, and the second tab called 'Statistics' will be used when we look at formula.
title: Filtering and pivot tables

body:
Spreadsheet applications have powerful formula functions to help you analyse the data. Here we are going to look at few of the simple formulas. 

This is where we will use the separate sheet in our spreadsheet for statistics. This means we will avoid including unnecessary tables in with our dataset or limiting the ability to add additional rows. All the formula used means that you can still add data to the original sheet and the statistics will automatically update in the second sheet. 

Again, you can use the video to help guide you.
title: Formula and statistics

_items.title: Averages
_items.body:
Calculating averages is a common operation with any numeric data. But remember, there is more than one type of average!

In the statistics sheet of the spreadsheet, we want to find out the mean and mode star ratings. These can be added by using the AVERAGE() and MODE() formula on the star rating column. 

To calculate the AVERAGE() star rating, type the following formula into the correct cell in the statistics sheet and then follow the instruction in italics. 

=AVERAGE( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

_items.title: Lowest and highest values
_items.body:
To find out what the lowest and highest star ratings are, you can use the MIN() and MAX() formula. 

e.g. 

=MAX( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

_items.title: Count the number of items
_items.body:
The COUNT() and COUNTA() functions help to count how many items there are in a large sheet. 

COUNT() and COUNTA() are two very similar functions. The difference between them is that COUNT() only counts cells containing numbers but COUNTA() counts all cells that aren't empty, meaning it will also count cells with text or other characters.

You can obtain the count of star rated facilities using the following formula. 

=COUNT( click Star Rating column in data sheet )

body:
A pivot table is a powerful data summary tool found in all spreadsheet tools. Among other functions, a pivot table can automatically sort, count, total or give the average of the data stored in one table or spreadsheet, displaying the results in a second table. Although not a charting tool in itself, a pivot table can produce the summary statistics needed when the desired output is a chart or some other sort of visualisation.

Pivot tables also give you the ability to "Pivot" or rotate the data, changing the column and row labels used from the original dataset. 

The example video demonstrates how to create a simple pivot table that gives the total number of health facilities per star rating. Here, the star ratings are used as the row labels and we have one column of data that represents the total count of facilities for each rating. 

Try following this through with your own dataset.
title: Pivot tables

displayTitle: Are you ready to filter and pivot data?
title: Are you ready to filter and pivot data?

body:
You may find something interesting in the data when you are cleaning, analysing and interrogating your dataset. If this finding is significant, the next stage will be to communicate this to others. Data visualisations help communicate insight found in data in an easy and quick way. 

In this module we are going to cover:

  • A brief history of data visualisation
  • Charts and distributions
  • Visualising data on a map
title: Data visualisation formats

body:
Most charts used in modern data visualisation derive from the original design of William Playfair (1759-1823), a political economist.

Playfair invented several types of diagrams: in 1786 the line, area and bar chart of economic data, and in 1801 the pie chart and circle graph, used to show part-whole relations.
displayTitle: A brief history of data visualisation
title: A brief history of data visualisation

body: Knowing which chart to use when communicating your story is essential to creating the right impact.
title: Essential charts

_items.title: Bar charts
_items.body:
The human brain is very good at quickly judging the size of simple shapes, such as rectangles. Thus the bar chart can very effectively communicate differences. 

Simple bar charts can communicate powerful messages quickly. Enhancing bar charts and pie charts with graphics and well placed text can also aid clear understanding. You do not even always need scales or lines.

The picture on the left compares the revenue of one product to the revenue of an entire company, where the product has made more money. If you were creating a visualisation which told this story, what might you add to make this finding stand out even more?

_items.title: Line and area charts
_items.body:
Line and area charts should only be used where there is a time series to be displayed. In most countries and cultures, people read left to right. Therefore, line charts must be constructed to be read from left to right. 

A line chart, as shown here, is best for comparing multiple sets of data over the same (or equivalent) timeframe.

An area chart can be used to emphasise the totals. When using area charts, it is best to use a stacked area to clearly show the total of all datasets over the same (or equivalent) period of time.
_items.strapline: Team GB Medal Olympic medal count comparison

_items.title: Histograms
_items.body:
Histograms should be used when a set of samples are taken at different points in time. For example, exam grades of different people or different heights, as shown here. 

A histogram is perfect for showing graphically where the median and mode lie. They also show the distribution (or shape) of the data and surface any outliers that might skew the location of the mean. 

Significantly, they can reveal whether the samples in your dataset are normally distributed, or contain data that might be skewed or falsified.

body:
Many datasets are related in some way to locations, and so visualising data on a map is the perfect way to make the data come to life. Care should be taken in creating the right type of map, and using the right features to direct the reader. For example, a map showing population across a large area should use a choropleth map. A map plotting 1000 densely clustered points would probably be better as a heat map, as the regions will be less defined and the grid size would be smaller. You can read further about the difference between the two maps here. 

The example shown on the right details all the empty and unused building in Detroit. Having the map showing all buildings is essential.

Aaron Koblin's flight patterns is a good example of a spatial visualisation that doesn't require an underlying map layer.

In Lloyd's, the City Risk Index uses a map to help people explore the impact on the economic output of 301 of the world’s major cities from 18 manmade and natural threats.
title: Maps

body:
Communicating impact from data is a key skill of any modern data worker. This module has introduced some of the essential formats and techniques that can help effectively visualise data.

Choosing the correct visualisation is the first step, but it does not guarantee that it will lead to an effective story. The visualisation will require careful design in order to make the story clear to the audience as we explore in the next module.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body: Check your knowledge with our test.
displayTitle: Are you ready to visualise data?
title: Are you ready to visualise data?

body:
Using a technique called 'pop out' helps direct the eye to the correct place. The dorsal stream reacts quickly to patterns and significant differences presented visually.

Pop-out works best when a combination of different visual cues are used in combination, e.g. colour, size and line thickness.

In the picture here, a combination of colour and thickness guides the eye towards the steepest line. This line represents the first high-speed train from Paris to Lyon. The steepness of the line is the speed.
title: Making information pop

body:
Visualising data enables us to grasp difficult concepts or identify new patterns quickly.

In this module, we introduce the key tricks that help the eye and brain process and understand data much faster. 

We will cover:

  • Visualisation and the visual cortex
  • Making information pop
  • Using color
title: Visualisation best practice

body: The human brain has been specifically designed to help us instantly process and react to what we see. Understanding how the visual cortex works is essential when creating powerful visualisations of data.
title: Visualisation and the visual cortex
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.
mobileInstruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.

_items.title: The human eye
_items.body:
The human eye, along with the visual cortex, is capable of processing trillions of points of information simultaneously.

The human eye is very sensitive to detail. It can instantly re-focus on objects at different distances. It can also instantly change the amount of light that enters the eye in order to deal with high and low light levels.  

Technologies such as Light Field cameras and High Dynamic Range which have the ability to capture a level of detail similar to the eye are beginning to emerge, but have taken thousands of years longer than the eye.

_items.title: The visual cortex
_items.body:
After light has entered the eye, the information carried with it is passed to the visual cortex for processing. This information is then split by the occipital lobe to be processed in parallel by the dorsal and ventral streams. 

These two pathways have very different jobs, and understanding each is the key to effective data visualisation. 

Dorsal Stream: The where/how path
Ventral Stream: The what pathway

_items.title: Fast path visualisation
_items.body:
The dorsal stream is the pathway in the visual cortex. It is responsible for recognising where things are and how they are going to affect you.

For example, if someone throws something at you unexpectedly, it's the dorsal stream that will react to help defend you. You act without thinking.

We can use the same trick in data visualisation to make information pop without needed to rely on the ventral stream to work out what that information is first.

body:
Appealing to the visual cortex helps us communicate strong messages, as they can provoke a reaction even before the rest of the brain has had a chance to process the information. 

Picking the right visualisation is only the first part of telling effective stories. Plotting the right data in the correct way, making good use of colour and other visual cues is essential to making the story “pop out” at the audience. This is essential to anyone who may be presenting their stories to high level manager with limited time. Even with limited time, this does not guarantee engagement. There are techniques that can create intrigue, but beware that they can also mislead...

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

displayTitle: Are you ready to put theory into practice?
title: Are you ready to put theory into practice?

body:
Not starting at zero causes what is known as 'baseline failure'.

When looking at a bar chart, the human brain looks instantly at the size of the bar, not the value it represents. Therefore, to make a value difference appear larger than it is, the scale won't start at zero. 

This is a very common trick used to emphasise a difference that would appear small otherwise.
title: Baseline failure

body:
As well as issues with area, pie charts can also be misleading when plotting percentages. 

A close look at this pie chart shows that the values only add up to 62%. So what happened to the other 38% of safety concerns?

It is also worth observing that the size of the 19% quadrant is also far larger than a 25% quadrant should be.
title: Percentages

body:
Visualisations should always be constructed to represent a true picture of the data. In communicating your message, make sure to avoid misleading your viewers. 

This module looked at the key techniques used and examined how to avoid being deceived. 

You may have created an engaging visualisation, but your audience might still struggle to understand the story without additional explanation or narrative.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
Visual representations of data vastly decrease the amount of time it takes to communicate a message. However, not all data visualisations are equal. In some cases, a combination of tricks are used to either emphasise a point or, in some cases, mislead the viewer. In this module we look at visual deception in data visualisation and how to avoid it.

In this module we'll explore the following: 

  • Baseline failure
  • Multiple scales
  • Adding depth and area
  • Percentages
  • Area and stacked area charts
title: Visual deception

body: The first thing that the brain notices when looking at a visualisation is the size of different parts.
title: Adding depth and area
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.
mobileInstruction: Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Adding depth
_items.body:
Adding 3D effects increases the area of a graph. To the human brain the perceived size is now larger with the additional volume. 

Providing that the volume is equal in all cases then this is fine (e.g. the volume of an area with value 4 is exactly twice the volume of an area with value 2). 

However, if the volumes are not proportional, or as is the case here potentially infinite, then it can be difficult to grasp real values.

_items.title: Removing depth
_items.body:
Removing the 3D infinite depth shows a different view of the data. 

With the depth removed, previously large changes are no longer present in the data. 

Interestingly, this data also suffers from the fact that the figures have not been adjusted for inflation. Adjusting the figures shows that state expenditure had not changed in real terms for the previous seven years.

_items.title: Radius and area
_items.body:
Using raw values as the radius of a circle is another big mistake. 

The easy way to spot this mistake is to attempt to fit a smaller circle inside a bigger circle. For example, a circle representing the value '1' should fit in another circle representing the value '3' exactly three times. 

As can be seen in the example here, this is not the case. Smaller differences seem bigger, due to the incorrect scaling of the circles.

body: Perhaps one of the most confusing charts ever created. Introducing area, stacked area and the stream graph.
title: Area and stacked area charts

_items.title: Area charts
_items.body:
Area charts are great for showing a single value that may consist of many parts. However if being used to compare two or more sets of values they should be avoided. 

Why? 

Because when the human brain looks at an area chart it sees mountains. Which means that one set of values is behind the other. 

This is correct for an area graph, so why should you not use them? Click to the next section to find out...

_items.title: Stacked area charts
_items.body:
The stacked area chart looks exactly the same as an area chart. However the two sets of values are now on top of each other not behind one another.

How do you tell?

There is no way for sure to tell what you are looking at unless it is stated. 

Take a look at both examples here as they use exactly the same set of source data. Can you tell the difference?

_items.title: Stream graphs
_items.body:
Going one step further and introducing the stream graph.

Is this stacked or an area chart? 

Where is the zero value on the y-axis?

Is the order of items significant?

Abandon all hope!

body: Try our quiz to see if you can avoid being deceived by data visualisation!
title: Can you avoid being deceived?

body:
Stories come in many different shapes and sizes. When you want to communicate a story, you need to decide how you want to share it and who you want your audience to be.

It may be that your data story is part of a wider bit of research. In this case, you might want to write a detailed book about it. However, books are a huge time investment, and will only be read by those who are already interested in your specialist subject. To maximise your impact and reach, your story needs to be easily shareable, searchable and succinct. 

This module will focus on writing compelling online articles and blogs to share your findings, give context to your visualisations and tell your story. 

Many different businesses and organisations now invest in blogging as an agile form of communicating ideas, projects and news to the wider world. When they are well structured and engaging they can attract widespread readership and help raise the organisation's profile. On the other hand, if they are not well structured, they can put people off and even pose a risk to the organisation's reputation.
title: Choosing the right format

body:
Once you have written your summary and gathered your resources, you should be well prepared to draft your story. If you think you don't have enough resources to write what is detailed in your summary, either return to gathering resources or tweak the summary to fit with what you know. Once you have finished, read through your draft and check it for the things that will make it engaging, accessible and accurate.

This checklist will help you make sure your blog is well-structured. Ask yourself:
title: Drafting your story

_items.title: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?
_items.body:
Think of your storyline as taking the shape of an arc.

Begin simply by setting the scene - what is the main takeaway of the article?

Then build up your story. Towards the end of the article, the reader should have all the information they need.

The ending hammers home the main takeaway of the story again, bringing together the main points covered throughout the article.
_items.strapline: Does my draft have a clear beginning, middle and end?

_items.title: Does my headline fit onto two lines?
_items.body:
Five times as many people will read the headline, as will read the rest of the article.

Ask yourself, 'what will make people want to read more?', and keep it short and snappy.
_items.strapline: Does my headline fit onto two lines?

_items.title: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?
_items.body:
Make sure you can substantiate your claims by pointing to the data and attributing where you can. 

Linking your publication to other websites and resources will also increase your story's exposure on the web.
_items.strapline: Does my draft include URL links (or footnotes)?

_items.title: Is there a call to action?
_items.body:
What do you want your readers do differently after reading the piece?

Whether your goal is to educate or inspire, motivate or amuse, make sure that you point towards the right resources for your readers to take action.
_items.strapline: Is there a call to action?

body: Once you're happy with your draft, take steps to getting your story out there.
title: Polish, Publish, Promote!

_items.title: 1. Polish
_items.body:
Read your draft through fully once more to make sure it is ready to launch.

Make sure all the hyperlinks are correct and link to active webpages, and be sure you have linked relevant content to the side panel if that is possible on the platform you are using to publish.

_items.title: 2. Publish
_items.body:
You should not see publishing your piece as the end of the process, but rather the beginning.

You want the blog to be read by the audience you had in mind when you wrote it, so make sure it is easy for them to find. Keeping Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) in mind when writing your headline is one of the ways in which you can make sure your piece will be visible to people who are interested in the subject of your blog.

_items.title: 3. Promote
_items.body:
Once you have published your piece, be sure to promote it using social media.

If you have quoted or mentioned specific people or organisations in your piece, link to their profiles on social media channels so they are notified and can easily share it. Asking your contacts or relevant organisations to share it across their social media channels can help you to get the widest possible reach.

body: Stories help us put data into the world. When put together effectively they can delight, enchant, inspire, educate, motivate and challenge us. Take a look a a number of the excellent examples here.
title: Great data journalism examples

_items.title: You Draw It: What Got Better or Worse During Obama’s Presidency?
_items.body:
In this piece of work by the New York Times they ask readers to engage directly with the story and challenge their existing knowledge. 

This can be a very effective way to not only entertain but also to directly educate users. This appears to learners who are very kinetic and like to learn by doing. 

Why not find out how much you know about the Obama years?

Explore this story
_items.strapline: You Draw It: What Got Better or Worse During Obama’s Presidency?

_items.title: In flight: 100 years of aviation
_items.body:
To mark 100 years of passenger air travel, the Guardian created an interactive story that used live data from FlightStats. The data allowed them to show every one of the thousands of commercial planes currently in the air.

This data was one of many datasets that were combined in this inteactive story to charts the history of aviation since 1914, and ask what comes next for the industry.

Explore for yourself

_items.title: American deaths in terrorism vs. gun violence
_items.body:
In the wake of the Oct. 1 shooting at Umpqua Community College in Oregon, President Barack Obama tasked the media to put the number of gun violence-related deaths into perspective.

Obama knew that the data was available and could be analysed in many ways, all with the same stark result (if you wanted to report it).

Explore the story at some of the links below:

CNN Washington Post 

Fox politifact
_items.strapline: American deaths in terrorism vs. gun violence

body:
Data increases in value the more it can be understood and shared.

In additional to a visualisation, build a shareable story around it and disseminate that story widely for maximum impact. 

So when you’ve found a  great story, make sure you tell it in a way that’s clear, relatable, and impactful.

When done effectively, telling data stories in the workplace can be a catalyst for change. Creating compelling stories is an essential skill for those who want to truly have impact.

Previous module Menu
title: Summary

body:
Data visualisations can be a powerful way of bringing data to life, and helping others deduce meaning from data.

But to add context to the visualisation, build a shareable story around it and disseminate that story widely for maximum impact, visualisations should be accompanied by a written narrative. 

This module goes through the steps you should take in putting your story into words for the best possible impact:

  • Choosing the right format
  • Planning and framing your story
  • Drafting your story
  • Polishing, publishing and promoting your story
  • Great data journalism examples

body:
One way to think about data is to consider who has access to it.

The Data Spectrum can help you to classify and agree on sharing arrangements for your data assets, from closed to shared to open.
title: The Data Spectrum
instruction: Click on each of the pins below to discover which data goes under which part of the spectrum.

_items.title: Internal access
_items.body:
'Internal access' relates to private data shared only with selected individuals inside an organisation.

Whether closed to protect sensitive personal information, such as salaries, or to keep commercially sensitive details of operations private, internal access data can only be accessed by those in specific roles within an organisation.

_items.title: Named access
_items.body:
'Named access' data is shared only with named individuals. These people can be inside an organisation or in partner organisations.

Named access data is accessed on the basis of a signed agreement between the party sharing the data and the party accessing it.

_items.title: Group-based access
_items.body:
'Group-based access' data is shared with anyone who meets certain conditions. For example, you might choose to share product availability quantities with anyone working for a retailer but not with those working for a competitor.

Group-based access is granted on the basis of authentication. The person accessing the data must prove, to the satisfaction of the sharing organisation, that they belong to the class of people granted access.

_items.title: Public access
_items.body:
'Public access' data can be located online by anyone. However, while people may be able to find this data, there are still legal protections in place that prevent its free use or sharing.

Your public access data is often part of your web presence or data you otherwise want people to experience without having the legal right to use and share it themselves.

_items.title: Open
_items.body:
'Open' data is data that anyone can access use and share. It is accessible without limitation to the public, subject to certain licence conditions such as the obligation to credit the source. 

Open data can be any non-personal data that its publisher deems beneficial to share without restriction.

body: Another way to think about your data is to consider its provenance. Lloyd's uses a provenance-based classification for data types.
title: Lloyd's data classification
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Lloyd’s internal data
_items.body:
Lloyd's internal data is data that is generated within the corporation through a Lloyd’s process. Lloyd's internal data may consist of numerical values or referential data.

For example, 'Funds at Lloyd’s', 'Central Fund asset disposition' and 'member participation'.

_items.title: Lloyd’s market data
_items.body:
Lloyd’s market data is data that is collected from the market and managed by the corporation. This includes Xchanging data.

Lloyd's market data includes numeric data that may be subject to quantitative controls such as data captured through Core Market Returns.

It also includes qualitative data that may be controlled by reviewing the method by which it was prepared. For example, the review of Managing Agent’s processes for preparing data that is submitted to Lloyd’s.

_items.title: Lloyd’s external data
_items.body:
Lloyd’s external data is data that is sourced externally from Lloyd’s.

For example, interest rates, exchange rates, and ISO geographical codes.

Explore more external data types below.

body:
Data is a valuable resource to organisations of all sizes. When used effectively, data can lead to new insights and bring benefits. Whether in operations, finance or products and services, organisations increasingly use data to understand how their business works and how they perform.

Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.

Find out more about the benefits of a data-driven approach in Unlocking value from open data and Convincing your colleagues.
title: Why do we need data?

body: There are different types of external data that you may come across. Below we explore some of the most common types of external data at Lloyd's and where they fit on the Data Spectrum.
title: External data types

_items.title: Reference data
_items.body:
Reference data is data that defines values to be used by other data.

Reference data becomes the most valuable when combined with other datasets.

Reference data can be open, shared or closed. For example, a dataset of country codes is open data. However, a reference dataset of risk codes or product IDs might be shared, either within an organisation (internal access) or between organisations (group-based access).

_items.title: Exhaust data
_items.body:
'Exhaust data' is data that is produced as a product of other data.

For example, on a telephone call the main data is the voices and what is said. Exhaust data includes the location of the callers, the length of the call in time, and the phone operators involved.

Where exhaust data exists on the Data Spectrum depends on the data. In the above example, it is likely to be shared by group-based access. This will depend on the terms and conditions of set out by whoever owns this exhaust data, for example, the phone operators.

_items.title: Open data
_items.body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

The most common open data licence is the Creative Commons CC BY licence.

body:
