body:
Data can be valuable resources for any organisation to make better use of their resources. However, most businesses are configured to protect their data resources, even where the benefits of greater sharing outweigh the costs.

The key to overcoming this resistance is clear, effective communication of the benefits that more effective use of data can bring to all staff so that improved data best practices become mainstream in all departments and teams. This module will prepare you to deliver a tailored pitch for more effective use of data.

In this module we'll explore how to:

  • structure the perfect pitch
  • tailor your pitch to different audiences
  • ensure you pitch is followed up
title: Convincing your colleagues

body:
Creating a pitch for improved data usage requires five components. When brought together, these create a clear, compelling case for action that can be used when seeking management approval, budgetary and resource support and downstream use and re-use. The pitch should be delivered in 90 seconds or less.

The five components of the perfect pitch are:

  1. What it is – the problem you are solving for your users
  2. What it can do – a tailored description of the benefit
  3. Where it's helped – a relevant, quantified proof point
  4. Why it's best – justification for why it beats other options
  5. What next – a realistic decision that can be taken on the spot

Below we explore each of these components in more detail.
displayTitle: The five components of the perfect data pitch
title: The five components of the perfect data pitch

body:
This is the part of your pitch where you can explain your value proposition in more detail. Don't worry about repeating yourself. Repetition is key.

The first time you said your value proposition, you wanted to catch your audience's attention. Now you have their attention, and you've explained the benefits for them, you can explain your solution in more detail.

This is also your chance to justify why your solution is better than alternative solutions. You can give competitive examples if relevant, or examples of where data has been shared with positive consequences to emphasise your point. 

Use a list of three for maximum impact, and remember: repetition is key.
displayTitle: Why improved data usage is best
title: Why improved data usage is best

body: In this section, we explore some existing case studies of improved data usage, group by the benefit they created.
displayTitle: Where has improved data usage already helped?
title: Where has improved data usage already helped?

_items.title: Growing the business
_items.body:
A global organisation, Arup uses data to complement many parts of its business.For example, the built environment department incubates data startups to complement its R&D department. The benefits include new revenue sources, lower operations costs, and collaborative commercial insights and different paths to market.

Monsanto bought the Climate Corporation for $930m in 2013. The Climate Corporation has revolutionised the agricultural industry. Its platform combines multiple data sources to help farmers improve their profits by making better informed operating and financing decisions.

_items.title: Improving efficiency
_items.body:
Thomson Reuters is a large organisation who uses data to link existing products together for a better sales channel. This has lowered ownership costs and reduced the price for their customers.

By releasing open data, the South Australian police have reduced the amount of Freedom of Information requests by 31%, saving the government time and money to process the requests.

_items.title: Improving products and services
_items.body:
Spotify uses open data service MusicBrainz to enhance the listening experience for its users and develop a competitive edge.

Another large organisation, Transport for London, released their travel data and enabled developers to provide consumer-friendly services, providing customers with an estimated £58 million per year in saved time.

Lloyd's has diversified its product offering thanks to increased used of data, with market intelligence products such as the Asia Performance Summary, Crystal and ISO services.

_items.title: Social impact
_items.body:
Nike created an app that ranks the environmental impact of common materials in their clothing and footwear. This enables users to compare the environmental footprint of the products.

Startup OpenSensors deployed air quality and noise sensors around Heathrow. Using the open data collected they exposed the fact that emissions were double the official reported figure. These results altered the direction of a parliamentary debate on the expansion of Heathrow airport.

body:
Improved data usage can bring different benefits, depending on its use.

Many advocates of improved data usage use generic arguments when discussing its advantages, but a strong pitch needs to be closely tailored to the priorities and concerns of the recipient of the pitch and the decision maker. In most cases, this can be determined from their professional context.

Below we examine six common roles in Lloyd's coupled with the most relevant benefits of improved data usage.
displayTitle: What improved data usage can do
title: What improved data usage can do

_items.title: Operations
_items.body:
For those in operations roles, efficiency is a priority. Data plays a role in resource-saving by enabling a faster exchange of information. Open data can enable efficiency in orders of far greater magnitude.

The ability to access and share data across multiple platforms and between numerous organisations eradicates the time and cost normally associated with acquiring valuable datasets, one by one.

_items.title: Finance
_items.body:
For those who work in finance, improving efficiency and providing evidence are likely to be the two most relevant arguments.

Internal more effective use of data will improve efficiency for the finance department. For example, sharing data between departments can smooth the departmental budget management process.

In the case of Lloyd's, data also allows Finance to provide evidence to regulators. For example, data can support capital modelling to prove that the Lloyd’s central capital fund is robust to be able to withstand market ‘shocks’ in the event of a catastrophic event that triggers large insurance claims.

_items.title: Performance Management
_items.body:
Data provides the evidence needed by performance managers to justify the decisions of the organisation.

Sharing data between departments also increases efficiency by removing silos in an organisation and the need to replicate the data multiple times. 

At Lloyd's, providing benchmarked analyses of market data both to the regulator (the PRA) and back to the market. This provides insight into how well the syndicates and managing agents are performing from a premium gross perspective.

_items.title: Global Market Intelligence
_items.body:
Improved data usage can help an organisation to identify new areas of growth.

In the case of Lloyd's, using datasets such as regional economic data and open regulatory data can help identify opportunities for a new Lloyd’s office in a growing economic region of the world.

_items.title: Exposure Management
_items.body:
For those working in exposure management, increased efficiency to spot trends and reduce risks earlier will be a convincing argument.

For example, by using internal market sensitive data from managing agent business plans, exposure managers can analyse and understand the financial exposure they have by a particular class of business.

_items.title: Communications
_items.body:
For those in communications roles, data can seem irrelevant to their work. The key message that resonates with communications professionals is that using data maximises opportunities for media exposure in support of promoting organisational priorities, demonstrating commitment to Corporate and Social Responsibilities and complements existing media channels.

Using data has a proven track record in helping to secure positive media coverage. The rise of data journalism has created a need for alternative channels that traditional releases and media alerts cannot reach. Verifiable data sources also increase perceived neutrality and trust among the public that resulting articles are not ‘spun’.

body:
Data can be valuable resources for any organisation to make more effective use of their resources. However, most businesses are configured to protect their data resources, even where the benefits of greater sharing outweigh the costs.

The key to overcoming this resistance is clear, effective communication of the benefits that improved data usage can bring to all staff so that improved data best practices become mainstream in all departments and teams.

Clear, effective communication of the benefits is essential to capture imaginations and gain trust and understanding. In this module we have learned how you can deliver a tailored pitch for improving data usage.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body:
The final component of the pitch is to leave your listener with a clear action.

Listeners want to be able to take action in response to a pitch. Your task is to create an action that allows them to immediately say yes (or no) without needing to think about it.
title: What next?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore.

_items.title: On the spot
_items.body: Make sure that your listener can respond to your action on the spot. If the person needs to consult others or consider further, the action is too big. The ideal is an action that is small, clear, and moves the agenda forward.

_items.title: Clear expectations
_items.body: Make sure that you set clear expectations in your ask. Keep the timeframe and the impact clear.

_items.title: Reasonable requests
_items.body: Only ask for budget or time that is reasonable, given the level of expected return. If your requests are unreasonable, you are unlikely to get a positive answer.

_items.title: Examples of good actions
_items.body:
​​​​Good actions don't have to change the world. Examples of good actions include:

  • Getting a date in the diary for a follow-up meeting with more people
  • Them committing to read and respond to a case study relevant to their interests
  • Them sending you a feasibility assessment of using your solution

displayTitle: Are you ready to convince your colleagues?
title: Are you ready to convince your colleagues?

body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains what quality data is, how to recognise it and which quality marques consumers of open data should look for.
displayTitle: Assessing open data quality - in 2 minutes
title: Assessing open data quality - in 2 minutes
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

body: The usability, trust and quality of a dataset can established by considering the who, what, where, when and why of the data. For publishers, the best practice guidelines should help provide answers to these aspects.
title: Data quality checklist
instruction: Explore each of these aspects below.

_items.title: Who?
_items.body:
Who owns the data?

Who publishes the data?

Who uses the data?

Who is permitted to use the data?

Who is permitted to change the data?

Who do you contact about the data?

All of these criteria help you establish the reach of the data and role of different actors with regards to this data.

_items.title: What?
_items.body:
What is the data about?

What format is the data in?

What data is included in the dataset?

What data has been removed?

What privacy concerns are there with this dataset?

What license is the dataset under?

The what is all about establishing the context of the data, expanding the understanding of who and working towards the other aspects such as when and why.

_items.title: When?
_items.body:
When was the data collected?

When was the data published?

When should you not use the data?

When (time) is the dataset about?

When is the data typically used?

All of these aspects build on the context of what the data is about to start establishing the story of the data over time.

_items.title: Where?
_items.body:
Where is the data collected?

Where is the data published?

Where is the data used?

Where is the data not used?

Where is the privacy impact to the data explained?

Where is the quality control process behind the data explained?

All of these aspects will help you refer back to the data, ensuring that the provenance of your usage of the data is clear.

_items.title: Why?
_items.body:
Why was the data collected in the first place?

Why is the data available to others?

Why is the data structured as it is?

Answering the answers about why certain decisions have been taken can often be challenging, but answering them can provide real insight into the history and potential of the data. Datasets that have achieved high levels of achievement with community standards will often be the easiest to answer these types of questions for.

body:
Data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

In many cases having a licence to use data has been a measure of quality and trust, but the licence alone is not enough to guarantee the usability and trustworthiness of the data. 

While the quality of data can be measured, usability and trust are subjective factors that are often influenced by external factors. 

Usability will often be measured in terms of how quickly the data can be integrated into existing systems.

Trust is all about reputation and authority of the provider and a measure of how complete the dataset is. If the data provider manages personal data, data privacy policies and compliance with data protections laws and regulations will play a key role. Many organisations may choose to publish a privacy impact assessment alongside their data to demonstrate due diligence. 

Helpfully there are a number of standards and guidelines that can help both publish and measure trusted, usable and high quality data.
title: Data usability, quality and trust.

body:
Lloyd's also has its own data quality checklist. The questions you should ask yourself are categorised under the headings of accuracy, completeness, appropriateness and timeliness.

You can read more about Lloyd's data quality governance and principles on the Lloyd’s IMAP website.
title: Lloyd's data quality checklist

_items.title: Accuracy
_items.body:
Accuracy refers to the degree of confidence that can be placed in the data. Data must be sufficiently accurate to avoid material distortion of the output.

Is the data free from mistakes?

Is data taken from different time periods consistent?

Is data recorded in a timely and consistent manner?

_items.title: Completeness
_items.body:
Completeness means that databases provide comprehensive information.

Is the data free of omissions?

Is the data sufficiently granular?

Does the data include sufficient information to assess the characteristics of the underlying risk?

If data is excluded, is that exclusion justified?

_items.title: Appropriateness
_items.body:
Appropriateness means that data does not contain biases which make it unfit for purpose. 

Is the granularity of the data sufficient to ensure effective controls are maintained?

Is the granularity of the data sufficient to allow for adequate actuarial and statistical techniques to be used?

Is the data used is relevant to its business purpose for which it is being analysed or used in the model (e.g. the portfolio of risks being analysed).

_items.title: Timeliness
_items.body: Timeliness means the provision of data should be timely as not to impact the completeness or accuracy of the data and how it is used and interpreted.

body: This course has been specifically designed to look at the entire process of using data to tell stories. Explore the stages below  to get an overview on how the course fits together.
displayTitle: Stages of the four step process
title: Stages of the four step process

_items.title: 1. Gathering data
_items.body:
In order to use data, you first need to have the data. 

Gathering data can be easy, if you know where to look. However the web also contains a lot of hidden data. Find out more in the gathering data module.

_items.title: 2. Filtering data
_items.body:
The four step process outlined above assumes that once you have data, you can immediately start filtering and using it. 

There are however several steps preceding the filtering of data:

Organising data

Data is likely to be gathered from many sources and it will be necessary to organise the data in a consistent way for analysis. 

Cleaning data

As you start to organise the data you are likely to note errors or inconsistencies in the data that require fixing.

Finally you can get around to... 

Filtering data

Once you have a usable dataset, it is finally possible to start filtering the data to find your story.

_items.title: 3. Visualising data
_items.body:
Once you have analysed the data, the next step is to visualise the data to highlight significant findings.

When it comes to visualising data, you need to consider three things:

Format: Which visualisation should you choose?

Clarity: Does the visualisation tell your story?

Intrigue: Does the visualisation engage or deceive?

_items.title: 4. Telling a story
_items.body:
In order to maximise impact of your story, you need a strong narrative which can relate to the desired audience at the right time. 

Find out more on writing your own narrative with the final module of this course.

body: A lot of data can be simply downloaded through clicking buttons. However, there are still challenges in finding this data in the first place and getting hold of it if there isn't a download button.
title: Finding downloadable data
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock downloadable data

_items.title: Data portals
_items.body:
Many suppliers are helpful and give you human-readable download links in order to obtain their data. For example, Lloyd's has a single webpage where market colleagues can download a restricted set of reports. 

Explore the links below to discover more:

  • data.gov.uk - Land Registry Monthly Property Transaction Data
  • School ranking data in Tanzania
  • School enrolment data in Kenya

_items.title: Power search for data
_items.body:
Many search engines, including Google, give you the ability to use advanced searches and prefixes in order to dig out data.

Try some of the following search prefixes in Google to see what you can find:

filetype:

Search for specific file types only, eg (xls) (example)

site:

Search with a specific domain or site only (example)

related:

Search for content related to a known page (example)

link:

List only pages that link to the one given (example)

_items.title: Aggregators and portals
_items.body:
Aggregators and portals bring together data from across the Web and expose it through their own service. This creates an easy and consistent way to find and download data.

Explore the links below to find out more:

enigma.io

Powerful open data searching for structured data

Transport API

All UK transport data, in one place, with one API

_items.title: Web scraping
_items.body:
If you can't simply download data in a usable format, you may need to scrape it. There are now many tools to help you achieve this easily:

pdftables.com

Upload a PDF, download data, simple. Try it out with this file.

magic.import.io

Extract data from webpages in a click. Try it on this page.

body: Unfortunately, there is no standard way to access all hidden data. Even though machines like clarity and structure, the humans that design them have implemented many techniques to add this structure.
title: Finding hidden data
instruction: Explore some of the main ways to unlock hidden data below.

_items.title: Extension downloads
_items.body:
Some websites have been built to offer a way to extract data by adding an extension to the URL of the webpage you are viewing. For such websites, usually maintained by organisations who also publish downloadable open data, adding the correct extension will trigger a download of that page in a data format, as opposed to a browser format.

A good example of this is the UK Government website (gov.uk) which provides any page in a data format simply by adding the relevant extension like “.json”, for example www.gov.uk/browse/business.json.

Try it with the UK Trade data by viewing the following page and then adding “.json” to get the data.
Take me to the UK gov trade tariff

To view the data in a more human readable form, copy it into jsonlint.com.

_items.title: Data feeds
_items.body:
Many websites provide links to data syndication feeds that can be subscribed to.

These feeds may be RSS feeds, Twitter alert feeds or other less common types. Feeds can be used to get raw data about a broad selection of content.

For an example of a raw data feed, look at the BBC news feed in XML.
Why not try out the news feeds from the BBC in XML?

Now you can use a free online tool to make that data easier to use 
Go to codebeautify and enter the BBC feed URL under 'Load URL'

or get alerts for flooding from your nearest river (UK only).
Take me to river level guages

_items.title: Source code
_items.body:
Going beyond providing a simple route to data, many sites have data embedded in the webpage's source code.

Why not check out the ODI's experimental 'Hidden Data Extractor' tool to find source code?

Take me to ODI Hidden Data Extractor

_items.title: APIs or machine-readable interfaces
_items.body:
Some websites or Web services will expose a machine-readable interface, or API, for querying and accessing their data.

Examples of services that have APIs include: Open Corporates (open),OpenSteetMap (open), Twitter (not completely open), Flickr (some content open), LinkedIn (not open).

Most of these services use a Web-based API and allow addition of extensions (try “.json” on OpenCorporates). Although this API looks the same as the earlier example in this section, its formal status as an API provides a guarantee that the service will be available.

body: Hidden data is...
title: Q: What is hidden data?

_items.text: data visible to machines but invisible to human eyes
files that are difficult to download

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the Web but that a machine can easily find and understand.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Hidden data is data that is invisible to people as they navigate the Web but that a machine can easily find and understand.

body: Which of the following is a useful way to extract hidden data from a website?
displayTitle: How might you extract hidden data from a website?
title: Q: How might you extract hidden data from a website?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Inspecting the source code of a website often reveals hidden data embedded in the page.

_incorrect.final:

body:
You can test what you have learned in this module by correcting a messy spreadsheet. 

Download and open this spreadsheet in your favourite spreadsheet application. Then see if you can fix the errors, relating to structure, content and layout, that you learnt about in this module. The spreadsheet contains two sheets of data from the same health facility star-ratings dataset, from different regions in Tanzania.

In order to track your changes on the spreadsheet, you may want to open a new tab or make a new spreadsheet. Create new columns, then add the records from the existing datasets into your new spreadsheet. 

In the next module we explore some other common data formats.

Previous module Next module
title: Summary

body: Just having a copy of the data does not guarantee that it is usable. A lot of time is wasted in exchanging data formats that are incompatible with common tools. In this section we consider what formats maximise the usability of data, ease of access for users and simple management for publishers.
title: Usability, access and management
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Usability
_items.body:
The most usable format for data is likely to be one in which the dataset was first created. In many cases, this format may be a proprietary software programme like Microsoft Excel. While such programmes often have the ability to export data in other formats, their popularity can make publishing in a different format a barrier to reuse by others.

Software programmes like Excel also come with richer content, such as styling on tables and graphs of data. These can all help to give context to a human who is trying to understand the data.

_items.title: Access
_items.body:
For data to be as accessible as possible, it must be:

  • In a format that the user can understand.
  • A format that machines can read.
  • In a format that supports the data's easy reuse.
  • In a format that doesn’t require expensive tools to access.

The format appropriate for each dataset may be different. A document (like a PDF) may make the data easy for a human to understand but not the most readable for a machine. For this reason, accessibility is often achieved by making the same data available in a range of different formats.

_items.title: Management
_items.body:
For some publishers, open data is now the main source for their data, even for staff in the publishing organisation. Using open data as a way for staff to access information inside an organisation has many benefits:

  • It increases knowledge of open data within the team.
  • It increases sustainability and trust in the data, by making it a key component of the organisation’s operations.
  • It creates clear opportunities for innovation.

body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.
title: Common errors in data
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: No known time zone
_items.body:
Related to dates are the problems of knowing the time zone of an event:

2017-02-08 21:00:00

With this example the use of the 24 hour clock tells us that this event is at 9pm. However in which time zone? The most common occurrence of this problem is when trying to arrange meetings across timezones.

Using a standardised date format, such as the ISO 8601 date format gives clarity to dates but does look complicated to the human eye:

2017-02-08T14:52:04+00:00

This ISO 8601 date format is the most widely recognised by computers. It consists of the date and time (separated by a "T") and an offset from Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). UTC is the same time zone at GMT (London) but does not observe daylight savings. 

If dates do not specify a timezone, then a machine will assume UTC and you could miss your flight by hours (or be very early for your flight).

_items.title: Multiple representations
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, it can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body:
Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800,000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, which causes errors.

Be careful with the UK decimal point (2.5) and the European decimal point (2,5).

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data is sometimes measured in ranges, such as age or salary range. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

body: Careful use of colour is essential and can help not only with 'pop out', but also conveying meaning.
title: Using colour
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how.

_items.title: Colour has meaning
_items.body:
As well as making information 'pop out', colour can also convey meaning.

For example: red, amber and green represent danger, caution, and safety. As shown in traffic lights. 

However, not all colours convey easily recognisable meaning, and too much use of colour can be confusing. In this way, try to keep the number of colours used to a minimum. 

A good demonstration of when to stop using too much colour can be found on this blog about Brexit.

_items.title: One colour
_items.body:
The human eye is much more sensitive to changes in a single colour rather than having to process multiple colours.

Grey scales (using different shades of the same colour) are useful to convey change, as the human eye has far more rods (low light receptors for grey scale) than cones (which handle different ranges of colour each).

_items.title: Picking the right colour
_items.body:
If you can't use a grey scale, then it is worth carefully considering the colours to use. Special care should be taken with colours that are too intense. 

Intense colours are those that combine colours which have long wavelengths, stimulating a lot of cones in the eye simultaneously. 

The most intense colour to the eye is yellow, as it combines the red and green receptor cones. 

As yellow can be glaring and hard on the eye, try using more neutral tones such as blue and purple, which are both used prevalently in design (such as in the Lloyds branding).

_items.title: Colour blindness
_items.body:
Approximately 4.5% of the population are colour blind.

Colour blindness affects intense colours like green and red much worse than blues and purples. To make matters worse these already intense colours are seen in many shades of yellow. 

The picture here shows the true colour spectrum on the left and the three different forms on colour blindness on the right. If any of the three on the right match the one on the far left then you suffer from colour blindness. 

When visualising data, try to use grey scales wherever possible. Only use colour where it already has a meaning.

body:
Another common method used to emphasise a difference or correlation is to use multiple scales. 

Typically, this involves having different scales on each side of the chart that each relate to different plots of data. 

The example shown here from the Colorado Department of Transport uses two scales to try and emphasise how different fatal accidents are in 2016 compared to previous years. 

Things to note:

  • The scale on the right does not start at zero (baseline failure)
  • The intervals on the two scales are different
  • The coloured bars for other years are not always for the same years (i.e. green is not always 2010)
title: Multiple scales

body:
In order to ensure your blogpost or article is well structured and engaging, it is important to take time to plan and frame your story.      

Before your begin to write, you can follow these three simple steps to make sure you have everything you need: setting out your structure, gathering your resources and drafting your headline.
title: Planning and framing your story

_items.title: Set out your structure
_items.body: Write a summary of your story with the main points that you want it to cover. It is helpful to use bullet points for this, being sure to cover the beginning, middle and end. (You might tweak these later, after having gathered your resources, but it will help to have this as a basis to draw on in the drafting stage.)

_items.title: Gather your resources
_items.body:
Once you have your draft structure set out, you can begin to gather your resources. 

You will need evidence to draw on in your story. This may come from information or quotes you find from another news story, a report, a book or an interview.

Be sure to carefully check the provenance of any sources to ensure that the data is reliable and trustworthy. Note down where the information is from and who wrote or said it. This will help with provenance checks and transparency. You should use this information to properly reference your sources when you come to drafting the piece. 

Learn more about gathering data here.

_items.title: Draft your headline
_items.body:
After having written your summary and gathered your resources you should have a good idea of what the focus of your piece will be. 

At this point it is very helpful to write a draft headline and standfirst (the two-sentence summary you see under headlines in news stories, usually in italics.) Again. this might change once you have written your piece, but it will help you to keep your main focus on mind as you write.
